item.title: ACF and PACF on Generated Data
item.description: Simulating Data Simulating data under an ARIMA model in R is made rather easy. From the documentation on arima in stats, we obtain that $$ X_t = a1 X{t-1} + a{2} X{t-2} + \ldots + a{p} X{t-p} + b1 \epsilon{t-1} + b[2] \epsilon{t-2} + \ldots + b{q} \epsilon{t-q} $$ by construction. This can be adjusted with the rand.gen argument. library(ggplot2) library(forecast) my.data <- arima.sim(list(ar=c(0.7,0.2)), n=100) my.data2 <- data.frame(x=seq(1,100), y=my.data) ggplot(my.

item.title: Instructors
item.description: Harold D. Clarke is Ashbel Smith Professor in the School of Economic, Political and Policy Sciences, University of Texas at Dallas, and adjunct Professor, Department of Government, University of Essex. His current research interests focus on the political economy of party support. He has published widely on this topic in journals such as the American Journal of Political Science, American Political Science Review, and British Journal of Political Science. He is chief editor of Electoral Studies.

item.title: Syllabus for 3K-2019
item.description: Modelling Dynamics and Heterogeneity: Time Series, Cross-Sectional Time Series, and Panel Data Harold D. Clarke, University of Texas Dallas and Robert Walker, Willamette University 5-16 August (two week course / 35 hrs) TOPICS The Core and Related Problems of Heterogeneity and Dynamics A Brief Review of Linear Models Summary and Visualisation of Time Series and Panels Using Stata and R to summarise and visualise single and multiple time series data

item.title: Topic 1 Readings
item.description: Day 1 Box-Steffensmeier, Freeman, Hitt, and Pevehouse, Chapter 1. Hsiao, Cheng, Why Panel Data? (September 6, 2005). IEPR Working Paper No. 05.33. Available at SSRN: https://ssrn.com/abstract=820204 or http://dx.doi.org/10.2139/ssrn.820204 or here

item.title: Topic 2 Readings
item.description: Univariate ARIMA Models Box-Steffensmeier, Freeman, Hitt, and Pevehouse, Chapter 2 and 5. Optional but strongly encouraged is their Appendix on Difference Equations. ARIMA Models in R. From Hyndman Falklands Intervention Clarke, et. al.. Harold will discuss this in the last 1.25 hours.

item.title: Topic 3 Readings
item.description: Time Series Regression Models Box-Steffensmeier, Freeman, Hitt, and Pevehouse, Chapter 3 and 4. Williams and Whitten, But Wait... dynsim

item.title: Topic 4 Readings
item.description: Cointegration and Error Correction Box-Steffensmeier, Freeman, Hitt, and Pevehouse, Chapter 6. Cointegration and ECM in R. From Colonescu, Chs. 12 and 13 Harold will discuss: Major’s lesser (not minor) effects: prime ministerial approval and governing party support in Britain since 1979

item.title: Topic 5 Readings
item.description: Heterogeneity in Single Time Series Box-Steffensmeier, Freeman, Hitt, and Pevehouse, Chapter 7. ARCH and GARCH From Colonescu, Chs. 14 Harold will talk about two of his pieces on this. They cover examples of ARCH/GARCH. They are: Tony Blair’s War and Clarke, Whiteley, Borges, Sanders, and Stewart. 2016. Modelling the dynamics of support for a right-wing populist party: the case of UKIP. JEPOP.

item.title: tidyquant
item.description: Some Basic Time Series with Equities First, let me get some data using tidyquant. tidyquant tidyquant automates a lot of equity research and calculation using tidy concepts. I will first use it to get the components of the S and P 500 and pick out those with weights over 1.1 percent. In the next step, I download the data and finally calculate daily returns and a cumulative wealth index.
